{{Globalize/US|date=December 2010}} '''Asian fetish''' is a [[slang]] term which usually refers to an interest, strong attraction or preference for people, culture, or things of [[East Asian people|Asian]] origin by those of Asian descent.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=aQu7avHHTm4C&lpg=PA134&dq=%22asian%20fetish%22&pg=PA134#v=onepage&q=%22asian%20fetish%22&f=false Korean American women By Ailee Moon pg 134]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,176330,00.html|title='Directors Want Freshness'|publisher=Time Magazine|author=Stephen Short|date=26 September 2001|accessdate=7 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/mwt/feature/2001/11/29/abandoned/print.html|title=Identity crisis|author=Theresa Pinto Sherer|publisher=Salon|date=29 November 2001|accessdate=7 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/02/fashion/sundaystyles/02tattoos.html?_r=1&pagewanted=print|title=Cool Tat, Too Bad It's Gibberish |author=Cindy Chang|date=2 April 2006|accessdate=7 November 2009|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> The term '''Asiaphile''' is sometimes used to describe the same phenomenon as is '''yellow fever'''.<ref name="Vicky">{{cite book | first=Vicky | last=Nam | title=YELL-oh Girls! | publisher=Harper Paperbacks |isbn= 0-06-095944-4| year=2001 | pages=131–132}}</ref><ref name="Phoebe">{{cite book | first = Phoebe| last = Eng | year = 2000 | title = Warrior Lessons : An Asian American Woman's Journey into Power | chapter = She Takes Back Desire | pages = 115–142 | publisher = Atria | location = New York|isbn = 0-671-00957-5}}</ref>
== Terminology and usage == For example, one website is called the "Asiaphile Homepage",<ref name="mystique">{{cite book | first = Sheridan | last = Prasso | year = 2005 | month = |title = The Asian Mystique | chapter = 'Race-ism,' Fetish, and Fever| editor = | others = | pages = 148–151 | publisher = Perseus Books | location = Cambridge, MA |isbn=978-1-58648-394-4 | chapterurl = | edition = }}</ref> while a Western academic specializing in Japanese miniature carvings prefers "Asiaphile".<ref name="Edwin">{{cite book | author=Edwin C., Jr. Symmes | title=Netsuke: Japanese Life and Legend in Miniature | publisher=Sheridan Prasso |isbn= 0-8048-2026-0| year=1995 | page=15}}</ref>
[[Ronald Lake]] uses the term{{Clarify|date=March 2010|reason=Which term? Asiaphile? Asian Fetisist? The distinction is very important here!}} as a label for people who invest mainly in Asian financial products.<ref name="Ronald">{{cite book | author=Ronald A Lake | title=Evaluating and Implementing Hedge Fund Strategies: The Experience of Managers and Investors, Third Edition | publisher=Euromoney Institutional Investor |isbn= 1-84374-051-6 | year=2003 | page=267}}</ref>
{{Wiktionary|Asiaphile}}
Other slang names for a preference for Asian sexual partners include "yellow fever", and "rice kings", "rice chasers", and "rice lovers" for the men who espouse it.<ref name=Chang>{{cite journal|title=Made in the USA: Rewriting Images of the Asian Fetish|author=Maggie Chang|work=Penn Humanities Forum on Word & Image, Undergraduate Mellon Research Fellows|url=http://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1005&context=uhf_2006|format=PDF|date=April 2006|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]}}</ref> The [[gay slang]] term used for a man, usually white, who exclusively dates Asian men is "rice [[Queen (slang)|queen]]."<ref name="GLAAD">{{cite web |url= http://www.glaad.org/poc/api/embracing_diversity.php|title= Embracing Diversity?|accessdate=2007-12-29 |last= Bohling |first= James|work= [[GLAAD]] |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071130030433/http://www.glaad.org/poc/api/embracing_diversity.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-11-30}}</ref><ref>Ayres T (1999). China doll - the experience of being a gay Chinese Australian. Journal of Homosexuality, 36(3-4): 87-97</ref>
In the afterword to the 1988 play ''[[M. Butterfly]]'', the writer, [[David Henry Hwang]], using the term "yellow fever," a pun on the [[Yellow fever|disease of the same name]], discusses white men with a "fetish" for Asian women. Hwang argues that this phenomenon is caused by [[stereotypes of East and Southeast Asians|stereotyping of Asians in Western society]].<ref name=Hwang>{{cite book | first = David Henry | last = Hwang | year = 1988 | title = M. Butterfly | chapter = Afterward | page = 98 | publisher = Plume Books | location = New York | isbn = 0-452-26466-9}}</ref>
In a collection of writings from [[Asian American]] females, ''YELL-Oh Girls!'', Meggy Wang calls a man "Mr. Asiaphile".<ref name="Vicky"/>
==Columbia study on racial preferences in dating== In 2007 economist Ray Fisman, in a two-year study he co-authored on dating preferences among Columbia University students, did not find evidence of a general preference among white men for Asian women. Furthermore, the study found that there is a significantly higher pairing of white men with East Asian women simply because East Asian women do not discriminate racially against white men, while women of other races do tend to discriminate against men of other races. As quoted on Slate.com,<ref name="slate.com">[http://www.slate.com/id/2177637/nav/tap3/ An Economist Goes to a Bar, and Solves the Mystery of Dating] Ray Fisman, Wednesday, November 7, 2007 - ''Slate.com''</ref> and also reported in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and the ''[[Review of Economic Studies]]'' (a publication of the [[London School of Economics]]):
{{cquote|We found no evidence of the stereotype of a white male preference for East Asian women. However, we also found that East Asian women did not discriminate against white men (only against black and Hispanic men). As a result, the white man-Asian woman pairing was the most common form of interracial dating—but because of the women's neutrality, not the men's pronounced preference. Men don't seem to discriminate based on race when it comes to dating. A woman's race had no effect on the men's choices.}}
The study was carried out over two years and was conducted by economists Ray Fisman (lead researcher from Columbia University) and Emir Kamenica (University of Chicago), as well as psychologists Sheena Iyengar (Columbia University) and Itamar Simonson (Stanford University). They took data from "thousands of decisions made by more than 400 daters from Columbia University's various graduate and professional schools."<ref name="slate.com"/>
